chapter.htmlHeader: Audit criteria
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The following National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) audit criteria are relevant for this CKS topic:

  • Audit criterion 10. Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy is offered to people who have tested positive for H. pylori and who have peptic ulcer disease.
  • Audit criterion 11a. For people with diagnosed peptic ulcer using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), NSAID use is stopped.
  • Audit criterion 11b. For people with diagnosed peptic ulcer using NSAIDs, full-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) or histamine (H2)-receptor antagonist (H2RA) therapy for 8 weeks is offered.
  • Audit criterion 11c. For people with diagnosed peptic ulcer using NSAIDs and in whom H. pylori is present, eradication therapy is offered after PPI or H2RA therapy.
  • Audit criterion 12. People with gastric ulcer and H. pylori are offered repeat endoscopy 6–8 weeks after beginning treatment.
  • Audit criterion 13. People with peptic ulcer and H. pylori are offered re-testing for H. pylori 6–8 weeks after beginning treatment.
  • Audit criterion 14. People who have tested negative for H. pylori and are not taking NSAIDs are offered full-dose PPI or H2RA for 4–8 weeks.
  • Audit criterion 15. People with previous peptic ulcer for whom continuation of NSAID is necessary and are receiving a NSAID are prescribed a PPI.
  • Audit criterion 16. In people with an unhealed peptic ulcer, the following are excluded:
    • Non-adherence.
    • Malignancy.
    • Failure to detect H. pylori.
    • Inadvertent NSAID use.
    • Other ulcer-inducing medication.
    • Rare causes such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome or Crohn's disease.
  • Audit criterion 17. If symptoms recur after initial treatment, a PPI is offered to be taken at the lowest dose possible to control symptoms.
  • Audit criterion 18. If there is inadequate response to a PPI, H2RA therapy is offered.

H. pylori testing

  • 1. H. pylori is tested for using a carbon-13 urea breath test or a stool antigen test or laboratory-based serology.
  • 2. Re-testing for H. pylori is performed using a carbon-13 urea breath test.
  • 3. Office-based serological tests are not used.

First-line H. pylori treatment

  • 4. People who test positive for H. pylori are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • either clarithromycin or metronidazole.
  • 5. People who are allergic to penicillin are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • clarithromycin and
    • metronidazole.
  • 6. People who are allergic to penicillin and who have had previous exposure to clarithromycin are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • bismuth and
    • metronidazole and
    • tetracycline.

Second-line H. pylori treatment

  • 7. People who still have symptoms after first-line eradication treatment are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • either clarithromycin or metronidazole (whichever was not used first-line).
  • 8. People who have had previous exposure to clarithromycin and metronidazole are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and
    • amoxicillin and
    • a quinolone or tetracycline.
  • 9. People who are allergic to penicillin and have not had previous exposure to a quinolone are offered a 7-day, twice-daily course of treatment with:
    • a PPI and 
    • metronidazole and 
    • levofloxacin.
  • 10. People who are allergic to penicillin and who have had previous exposure to a quinolone are offered:
    • a PPI and
    • bismuth and
    • metronidazole and
    • tetracycline.
  • 11. If eradication of H. pylori is not successful with second-line treatment, advice is sought from a gastroenterologist.

[NICE, 2014]
